entry.title: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JDBC
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)  
 
JDBC – JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY 
 
Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API : 
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access. 
 
Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging 
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. 
 
Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).  
 
For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section. 
 
Prerequisites: 

  1. SAP DataSphere – Subscribed account (⚠ Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported) 
  1. SAP Integration Suite – Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported) 

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide : 
 

Step 

Action / Notes 

1. Create a Space 

DataSphere → Space Management → New Space → Name it → Create. 

2. Create Table / Analytical Model 

Data Builder → In your Space → New → Table or Analytical Model → define fields & data types → Save & Publish. 
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. * 

3. Prepare / Load Data 

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration. 

4. Note Schema & Object Names 

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use. 
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name * 

5. Decide Where to Create DB User 

If HANA Cloud → use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB → use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin. 
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session* 

6. Create JDBC DB User 

DB admin tool → Security/Users → New User → set username & strong password → Save. 
*Check Active status of User* 

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user 

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign. 

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details 

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com 
Format for CPI JDBC Material: 
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true 

 
SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide : 
 
Create a Package & Artifact 

  • In CPI → Design → Create a new package → Add an integration flow artifact. 
  • ✅ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts. 
     

Go to Monitoring → JDBC Material 

  • In CPI → Monitor → Integrations and APIs → Manage Security → JDBC Material

     

     
  • → Add JDBC Data Source. → Select HANA cloud  

     

     
     
  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true). 

     

     
  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere). 

     

     
  • Save and deploy the JDBC material. 
    •  

    Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

    • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter → select the JDBC data source created.
    • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I’m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

     


    Step 1: Timer Start
     In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule → None → On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

     


    Step 2: Content Modifier
    Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
     SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

     



    Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
         → Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
    → JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

     


    Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

     



    References :

    CPI JDBC – XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
     link:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: Re: Beginners Guide to Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
Hi,

I’ve also been running some tests with AEM and CPI, and I’m having trouble achieving EO (Exactly Once) behavior with scheduled resends (e.g., after one hour).

When a message fails, it gets stuck and blocks the corresponding node consumer. Eventually, after several failures, all CPI consumers end up blocked by failed messages.

As a result, no new messages are consumed until those failed ones are rejected—usually hours later, depending on the CPI sender adapter’s redelivery configuration.

What configuration or combination of queue and adapter would you recommend to avoid this blocking behavior while still keeping the redelivery settings active in CPI?

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Enabling the HTML5 Applications Repository in SAP BTP
entry.content:
This Blog explain the how to enable the HTML5 Applications repository

At first we need to enable the 2 things successfully like 

1. Cloud Identity Services

2. SAP Build Work Zone

In the very first step is to click the Create option in your Instances and Subscriptions tab

In this New Instance Window click on Cloud Identity Services then Plan will be default

Service: Cloud Identity Services

Plan: default

Once you done click on Create in the Bottom of the Screen

Once you have create the above service successfully then we need to move on to the Users tab then click on user we need and click on Assign Role Collection

Once you click on that the Assign Role Collection Dialogue will open then we need to search and assign the roles in below

Cloud Connector Administrator, Connectivity and Destination Administrator, Subaccount Service Administrator, Subaccount Viewer

Once you have assigned the role it will looks like below

After completing the above step, please check your email for a message regarding identity authentication. Click the link provided in the email to activate it and verify your account.

 

 

Once you click on the link the Cloud Identity service will open if not just go the Cloud Identity service which was in your BTP Instance and service

 

 

Once you have verified through mail move to the Instances and Subscriptions tab click on Cloud Identity then click Go to Application

 

Once you have done you will see this page Cloud Identity Services in this click on User Management

After clicking the User Management verify the user credentials here

Then move on the Trust Configuration Part under the Security then click on Establish Trust the configure Tenant pop up will open

In this select the Default value 

In this choose Domain option choose option end with ‘trail-accound.ondemand.com’

Then click on create to sap build work zone

With this you can go for standard subscription plan

We have successfully activated the sap Build work zone

 

Then will check on HTML5 Applications tab you can see HTML5 application now allow to add application here, Thank for Reading!

entry.title: Re: Possibility of Restricting Access to Specific Billing...
entry.content:
Dear customer, you can use app authorization variants (a type of IAM app) to fulfill this business requirement.

This concept enables you to assign authorizations to individual users on a per-app level. So you can build roles that, for example, only contain authorizations for the Create Billing Documents and Display Billing Documents apps, and another role specifically for the Manage Billing Documents and Change Billing Documents app.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/e2b39fb01689420393931a9eb3f627ec.html?version=2508.500

entry.title: Read more on Confirmed' or 'Confirmed Automatically cases and what can be done?
entry.content:
Here is all you need to know if a case is confirmed or confirmed automatically, and you still need support from SAP 

What does Confirmed and Automatically Confirmed mean?  

Confirmed — The case was closed by the customer and can no longer be reopened. The case can be found in the Closed Cases section of the case list.   

If a case is ‘confirmed automatically’ it means that case was in one of the below statuses for over 21 days with no response from the customer and can no longer be reopened.   

  • Customer Action  
  • SAP Proposed Solution  

Read more on this here SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA) 1929454 - What is the time for the automatic closure of support cases and 2537073 - What is the time for automatic closure of support  

 A case that is 'Confirmed' or 'Confirmed Automatically’ cannot be reopened however what can be done with a valid S-user ID within the organization and has the correct authorizations is create A New Case - About the User, Authorization, and Administrator Concept   

When creating the new case ( 1296527 - How to create a support case for SAP Support - SAP for Me) when filling out the  Description ensure to mention the previous case number that is confirmed.   

 

The relevant team will then know that the new case is related to a previous one that is confirmed, and the new case will be picked up from where the previous case was processed.

We suggest that if SAP has requested information on the confirmed case, you should include the reply in the new case to ensure the most efficient support.  

Thanks for reading!      

We hope you found this useful.

Please note that the Customer Interaction Center is always happy to guide you on any of the mentioned processes and assist you with any queries you may have.    

If you have any questions, please ask a question in the Q & A using All Questions in Customer Experience | SAP Community and All Questions in Support Services | SAP Community   

Read more #CustomerInteractionCenter blogposts "CustomerInteractionCenter" - SAP Community

entry.title: Flexible Programming Model sortOrder ignored by macros Table
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I have a FPM project with first view containing macros Filterbar und Table.

The table displays the data, but ignores the CDS Annotation SortOrder from the PresentationVarian:

@ui.presentationVariant: [{
qualifier: 'DefaultSorter',
sortOrder: [{ by: 'ManufacturingOrder', direction: #DESC }],
visualizations: [{type: #AS_LINEITEM }]
}]

I even added the property to the manifest file:

"defaultTemplateAnnotationPath": "com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.PresentationVariant#DefaultSorter",

I can see in the oData metadata the annotation is present.

I am currently using the 1.120.0 version, but the same result is with 1.141.3

Is there any additional property expected by the macros table? In the API Dokumentation it is written :
Usually, a LineItem, PresentationVariant, or SelectionPresentationVariant annotation is expected, but the Table building block can also be used to display an EntitySet.
If a PresentationVariant is specified, then it must have UI.LineItem as the first property of the Visualizations.

 

Thanks for you help!

entry.title: Co-Innovate with us: Introducing the AI-Assisted Message Monitoring Agent for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
We're excited to invite you to be a part of the new SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI) for the AI-assisted message monitoring agent for SAP Integration Suite. This is your chance to help influence our product development and shape the future of our product.

By participating in this initiative, you will gain valuable early insights into our latest AI feature developments. You'll have the opportunity to work directly with our product experts and see first-hand how we’re innovating solutions in areas such as error handling, version management, activity tracking and assessments for maintenance strategy using AI-generated recommendations.

Register your interest, and we’ll follow up with details on the virtual workshops and pilot opportunities. Here you can register by 14 November!​

 

See how our AI Agent transforms error handling in SAP Integration Suite

Rather than relying on manual monitoring, the agent continuously analyzes message executions to identify anomalies, failed runs, and performance deviations. Leveraging contextual insights from logs and runtime data, the agent detects potential root causes and recommends guided error resolution. This enables faster incident resolution, minimizes handovers, and ensures operational consistency.

 

Our vision extends beyond conversational assistance — toward intelligent agents capable of autonomously performing operational tasks. These agents aim to reduce expert dependency, automate repetitive processes, and empower users to focus on strategic and value-adding work.
We are starting with operational efficiency use cases and will progressively expand into broader business and user-centric scenarios. Together with our co-innovation partners, we seek to define the right balance between autonomous AI execution and human oversight.

#SAP Integration Suite #AI agents

entry.title: Learning Circle Experience Change Management 2025 - Zusammenfassung des ersten Boxenstopps
entry.content:
Die Learning Circle Experience erstreckt sich über einen Zeitraum von 12 Wochen, in denen vier zentrale Online-Termine mit allen Teilnehmenden stattfinden. Zwischen diesen zentralen Sessions arbeiten alle in kleinen Lerngruppen von 5-6 Personen und treffen sich wöchentlich für etwa eine Stunde, um ein Kapitel und eine Übung des LernOS Change Management Leitfadens zu reflektieren. Anbei eine Zusammenfassung des ersten Boxenstopps. Ich fand vor allem die Reflektion der Lernerfahrungen spannend. Anbei die Struktur der Gruppenteilnehmenden. 

 

Lernerfahrungen & Inhaltliche Erkenntnisse

Rollentrennung als wichtige Erkenntnis: Für viele Teilnehmende war die klare Unterscheidung zwischen Projektleiter- und Change Manager-Rolle und Aufgabe der wichtigste Lerneffekt. Diese werden in der Praxis häufig vermischt oder gleichgesetzt - “Für mich war es auch der klare Unterschied zwischen der Rolle PL und Change Manager.”

Erfolgreicher Praxistransfer: Die Leitfaden-Kapitel führen erfolgreich zu Diskussionen über aktuelle Projekte. Der theoretische Input wird direkt auf reale Situationen angewendet - “Wir sind über die Kapitel in den Austausch zu aktuellen Projekten gekommen - sehr hilfreich.” 

Lernformat & Strukturelle Erkenntnisse

Leitfaden als Orientierungshilfe: “Leitfaden ist super zur Orientierung/Abstimmung” - gibt einen klaren roten Faden durch die Change Management Grundlagen. Die Struktur wird von den Gruppen als hilfreich empfunden, auch wenn inhaltliche Tiefe gewünscht wird.

Hybride Lernansätze funktionieren: “Mir hilft der Austausch in der Gruppe auf der Ebene der Schlagworte. Die Vertiefung mache ich dann nach meinem Bedarf über KI-gestützte Ansätze” - zeigt einen innovativen Ansatz, wo Gruppenlernen und individuelle Vertiefung kombiniert werden.

Personalisierte Wissensaufbereitung: “Bei uns schreibt sich jeder die für ihn relevanten Punkte selber auf” - individuelle Dokumentation parallel zum Gruppenaustausch hat sich bewährt. Teilnehmende filtern aktiv die für sie relevanten Inhalte heraus.

Erwartungsmanagement funktioniert: Die Teilnehmenden verstehen, dass es sich um Grundlagen handelt, nicht um eine Expertenausbildung. Dennoch wird der Leitfaden als Inspiration für weiterführendes Lernen genutzt: “Ich hab auch schon ein paar Bücher aus dem Leitfaden bestellt für das Selbststudium.”

Gruppendynamik als Lernfaktor

Koordinator als Erfolgsfaktor: “Wir haben einen sehr guten Koordinator” - erfolgreiche Gruppen haben meist eine Person, die die Organisation übernimmt und die Gruppe zusammenhält.

Erfahrungsmix als Bereicherung: Gruppen mit unterschiedlichen Erfahrungslevels profitieren enorm voneinander. Erfahrene Change Manager können Kontext geben, während Einsteiger frische Perspektiven einbringen.

Best Practices werden intuitiv angewendet: “Wir verwenden intuitiv die auf der vorherigen Seite gezeigten Best Practices und ziehen die Termine auch in kleinerer Anzahl durch” - Gruppen adaptieren die gelernten Methoden flexibel an ihre Situation. 
FYI Anbei die Best Practices die ich präsentiert habe. 

Inhaltliche Herausforderungen & Verbesserungsbedarf

Ungleiche Tiefe: Die Kapitel haben sehr unterschiedliche Granularität - Stakeholder Management ausführlich, Widerstände nur oberflächlich behandelt. Dies führt zu ungleichmäßigen Lernerfahrungen.

Komplexität vs. Überblick: Viele Themen werden nur angerissen. Beispiel ADKAR: “steht da mit 3 Sätzen drin, aber ADKAR füllt ja Tage”. Für Change-Einsteiger ist oft nicht bewusst, wie umfangreich die Themen sind. “Bislang waren die Lerninhalte nicht sehr fordernd. Ich hatte mir mehr Tiefe erhofft.”

Wissenslücken-Problem: “Die Herausforderung ist häufig, dass unerfahrene Projektmanager gar nicht wissen, was sie nicht wissen” - ein zentrales Problem beim Selbstlernen ohne erfahrene Begleitung.

Alltags-Integration & Praxisbezug

Zeitmanagement als Herausforderung: “Herausforderung: Neben dem Projektalltag die Katas durchzugehen” - zeitliche Belastung ist real, aber durch gute Gruppenabstimmung lösbar.

Community-Learning funktioniert: “Austausch mit anderen Praktikern ist für mich der messbare Mehrwert” - das Peer-Learning-Format liefert den versprochenen Nutzen.

Innovative Lernmethoden & Tools

KI-Integration als Game Changer

  • Solo-Learning mit KI-Support: “Ich bin als Solo-Lerner unterwegs und mir hilft, dass ich mir von ChatGPT wöchentlich Mo/Mi/Fr Trigger und Wissenstests zu den Katas und Grundlagen schicken lasse. Das hilft, dass das Thema im Arbeitsalltag nicht untergeht.”
  • Content-Personalisierung: “Den Leitfaden in ein KI-Tool hochzuladen und damit zu lernen und die Inhalte gleich auf das eigene Szenario anpassen zu lassen funktioniert super gut.”
  • Multimedia-Transformation: “Bei uns wurden die Inhalte mit KI in Videos & Podcast umgewandelt, was das Lernen nochmal stark unterstützt hat. Super als Side-Learning und KI Usecase.”

Bewährte Gruppentools

  • TaskCard-Board: “Wir nutzen ein TaskCard-Board. Da können wir von Kata zu Kata Notizen und ‘Hausaufgaben’ eintragen” - strukturierte Dokumentation über den Lernverlauf
  • Miro/Mural: “Wir haben auch jede Woche ein Update und fassen die Journey in einem Mural zusammen” - visuelle Dokumentation des Lernfortschritts
  • Regelmäßige MS Teams-Sessions: “Es funktioniert sehr gut. Regelmäßige MS Teams Session eingerichtet. Der Austausch und gegenseitige Fragen helfen.”
  • Security-Workarounds: “Security Einstellungen -> Probleme bei gemeinsamer Arbeitsplattform/Chats über Teams teilweise nicht möglich gewesen. Aber durch regelmäßigen Austausch & Miroboard gut abgefangen”

Strukturierte Gruppenarbeit

Praxisorientierter Austausch: “Wir tauschen uns in der wöchentlichen Runde entlang der Aufgabenstellungen (Katas) aus unseren praktischen Erfahrungen aus. Wir sind immer sehr praxisorientiert unterwegs.”

Dokumentationsvielfalt: Von OneNote-Notizen über Teams-Chats bis hin zu kollaborativen Boards - jede Gruppe findet ihre optimale Dokumentationsform.

Praktische Herausforderungen & Lösungsansätze

Konkrete Praxisfrage: “Wie man im Change- und Projektmanagement damit umgeht, wenn man zum Beispiel die SAP Activate Methode anwendet, im Rahmen eines SAP S4/HANA-Changes aber nur Projektleitende einsetzt, die keine zusätzliche Change-Erfahrung haben, bzw. zu wenige Ressourcen dafür zu haben. Ist es realistisch, dass ein Projektleitender ohne Change-Erfahrung einen Change erfolgreich umsetzt?”

Community-Antworten:

  • “Wenn das Projekt so klein ist, dass es keinen Changemanager stellen kann, sollte sich der Auftraggeber/Sponsor kümmern, nicht der Projektleiter”
  • “OCM hat starken Bezug zur Stammorganisation”
  • “Der Stellenwert von Change Management unterscheidet sich stark von Unternehmen zu Unternehmen. Bei uns wird Change Management nicht explizit erwartet, auch bei größeren Projekten nicht.”
  • Hier hilft Versachlichen (xy passiert wenn kein Change Management), Eskalieren und das sog. Management Alignment - sprich Absprache mit den Sponsoren
  • Rechtzeitige Eskalation: “Besser ist es, wenn ich Dinge vorher feststelle und aufzeige, was alles nicht gemacht werden kann”
  • Konsequenzen aufzeigen: Business Case für Change Management durch Darstellung der Risiken bei Verzicht
  • Ganz allgemein wird glücklicherweise zunehmend die Notwendigkeit von Change Management gesehen. Bei uns (SAP) wird das zunehmend adressiert, aber auch sehen wir mehr Change Rollen und CoEs bei Beratungspartnern und Kunden. 

Gruppendynamik & Organisation

Erfolgreiche Gruppenmodelle

Stabile Gruppen mit guter Dynamik: “Ich finds prima - unsere Südwestchanger Gruppe passt gut zusammen, wir haben das Thema Tools gelöst, noch eine zusätzliche Kollegin in unsere Gruppe mit aufgenommen und spannende Fragen diskutiert.”

Better Together Gruppe: “Der Austausch ist immer praxisnah und bringt viele wertvolle Einblicke” - fokussiert auf konkrete Anwendungsfälle und Erfahrungsaustausch.

Organisatorische Herausforderungen

Gruppenschrumpfung: “Wir waren zu fünft am Anfang. Dann im Termin zu dritt, dann zu zweit. Dann nur noch ich im wöchentlichen Call” - typischer Verlauf bei einigen Gruppen.

Terminfindung: “Termine zu finden, die bei allen passen, ist nicht immer leicht” - besonders herausfordernd bei organisationsübergreifenden Gruppen.

Lösungsansätze: Aktive Aufnahme neuer Mitglieder, flexible Termingestaltung, Unterstützung durch Community-Koordination.

Aktueller Stand & Ausblick

Inhaltlicher Fortschritt

  • Abgeschlossen: Einführung Change Management, Stakeholder Management, Kommunikation
  • Nächstes Thema: Lernen und Weiterbildung

Community-Entwicklung

Nachzügler-Integration läuft: Mehrere Gruppen nehmen aktiv neue Mitglieder auf. Gruppen reorganisieren sich bei Bedarf und finden pragmatische Lösungen für organisatorische Herausforderungen. Bei Fragen, Problemen meldet Euch bitte direkt bei uns oder in der LinkedIn Gruppe. 

Diskussion über den Leitfaden

  1. Inhaltliche Optimierung: “Manche Leitfäden haben ein Kapitel mit ‘Weiterführenden Informationen’… so könnte man z.B. ‘Deep Dives’ zu ADKAR & Co. einbauen” - gebt uns bitte Feedback am Besten direkt in GitHub - ich habe die ersten Feedbacks dort alle schon umgesetzt. 
  2. KI-Integration fördern: Best Practices für KI-gestütztes Lernen aktiv in der Community teilen (dazu rufe ich nochmals auf 🙂
  3. Praxisbezug stärken: Kaffeeecken mit Fallstudien (Siehe Kaffee-Ecken und deren Doku in der Community Gruppe). 
  4. Balance: Zwischen Einsteigerfreundlichkeit und ausreichender Tiefe für Erfahrene.  

Wichtig war und ist für mich auch nochmals die Zielsetzung des Leitfadens: Hier geht es um Basics für Menschen, die gerne mehr über Change Management lernen wollen. Wir können den Leitfaden mit Links ergänzen, es bleicht aber ein Grundlagenwerk. Evtl. gibt es zu einzelnen Bereichen einmal eigene Leitfäden als Vertiefung. Für mich entsteht Lernen zudem vor allem aus der Reflektion und Diskussion besonders hinsichtlich der konkreten Praktik von jedem. 

Community-Highlight: Die Abstimmung um den originellsten Gruppennamen gewannen “Shift Happens” und “Control Alt & Change” mit jeweils gleicher Stimmenzahl - beide Teams erhalten die begehrten “Activate Human Superpowers” T-Shirts. Ich freue mich schon auf die Selfies :-). 

Nächste Termine: Boxenstopp 18.11. (eventuell bei Teilnehmer vor Ort) - abschliessend die Retrospektive 16.12.

entry.title: Re: In EPPM, what's the accrual revenue calculation metho...
entry.content:
Is this Public Cloud?

The calculation is POC = (Total Actual Cost) / (Total Plan Cost) then the POC is multiplied by the (Total Planned Revenue) to get the Recognized Revenue.  The Recognized Revenue is compared to the Actual Revenue and then either a posting for Revenue Accrual or Revenue Deferral is made to true things up.

The Total Actual Cost and Total Plan Cost are a summation across all G/L Accounts.  It does not calculate a POC for each G/L account.

Yes, there are details in configuration.  

Look here for detailed posting logic:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/23cee4ab4c5443c6b68e274e69dcf19f.html

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM: Your Single Pane of Glass for Managing the Modern SAP Landscape

Managing an SAP landscape today can feel like trying to solve a Rubik’s Cube blindfolded. Gone are the days of a single, monolithic system. Now, your digital core spans SAP S/4HANA (Cloud and on-premise), plus a growing collection of cloud solutions like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and SAP Concur.

All this innovation comes with a cost: complexity. Teams juggle multiple tools, data gets siloed, processes break down, and IT often ends up firefighting instead of driving innovation.

But what if there were a better way—a way to see everything clearly, act proactively, and actually enjoy running your SAP landscape?

Enter SAP Cloud ALM.

What Makes SAP Cloud ALM Different?

SAP Cloud ALM is a cloud-native solution designed to simplify how you manage your SAP environment. It’s included with your SAP cloud subscription—no extra licenses, no additional hardware, no hidden costs. Just one intelligent platform to manage your entire landscape.

Here’s how it helps you and your teams:

1. See Everything in One Place

Imagine having a single dashboard that shows the health, availability, and performance of every SAP system you run—S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, and more. No more toggling between tools or digging through emails to figure out what’s happening. You get a real-time, holistic view of your SAP ecosystem.

2. Predict Issues Before They Happen

Reactive problem-solving is exhausting. SAP Cloud ALM helps your teams move from putting out fires to preventing them. Machine learning detects anomalies in your critical business processes—like Order-to-Cash or Procure-to-Pay—so you can fix potential issues before they affect your business.

3. Make Implementations Smooth and Predictable

Implementing SAP projects can feel like herding cats. With SAP Cloud ALM, task management is aligned with the SAP Activate methodology, giving project teams a clear roadmap from discovery to go-live. Everyone knows their responsibilities, deadlines, and dependencies, reducing miscommunication and risk.

Real Impact: Stories from the Field

Let’s put these capabilities into perspective with real-world scenarios:

For IT Operations Leaders:

  • The challenge: Constantly reacting to system issues, juggling multiple monitoring tools, long resolution times.

  • The solution: Consolidated alerts and predictive insights from Cloud ALM.

  • The result: 40% reduction in unplanned downtime, 50% faster resolution times, and IT becomes a trusted business partner rather than a cost center.

For Project Managers:

  • The challenge: Complex S/4HANA implementations with distributed teams and unclear responsibilities.

  • The solution: Centralized task lists and progress tracking within SAP Activate.

  • The result: Shorter project timelines, fewer risks, and more confident, on-budget go-lives.

For Business Process Owners:

  • The challenge: Lack of visibility into end-to-end processes, discovering bottlenecks too late.

  • The solution: Business process monitoring dashboards provide live insights into performance and exceptions.

  • The result: Faster cycle times, smoother operations, and better decisions based on real-time data.

Your Path to Smarter ALM

If you’re still using SAP Solution Manager, don’t worry—SAP provides clear guidance and tools to transition to Cloud ALM smoothly. The future of ALM is cloud-native, predictive, and integrated, helping you focus on business value instead of firefighting.

Take the Next Step

  • Explore More: Visit the SAP Cloud ALM homepage for details.

  • Join the Community: Share experiences, tips, and best practices with peers in the SAP Community.

  • See What’s Coming: Track updates and features in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Stop managing your SAP landscape through a keyhole. With SAP Cloud ALM, you get the big picture, the predictive insights, and the operational simplicity to make your digital core truly work for your business.

Cloud ALM Application insights

entry.title: Streamlining List Management in SAP Concur with Real-Time API Integration
entry.content:
Introduction

As a Technical Consultant at SAP Concur, I’ve helped many clients streamline their integrations. One recurring challenge? Keeping lists accurate and up-to-date. That’s where our new List Management Use Case comes in.

Managing dynamic lists—such as departments, project codes, or cost centers—is an important part of ensuring accurate data entry and enforcing business rules in SAP Concur.

The Challenge: Keeping Lists Accurate and Up-to-Date

In many organizations, the system of record for lists resides outside of Concur. Whether it’s a fast-growing company with frequent organizational changes or a global enterprise managing complex hierarchies, the need for real-time list synchronization is clear. Manual updates via the UI or Excel templates are time-consuming and error-prone, and overnight batch jobs can’t keep pace with dynamic environments.

The Solution: SAP Concur List & List Item APIs

This use case introduces a robust, API-driven approach to list management. By leveraging SAP Concur’s List v4 and List Item v4 APIs, organizations can:

  • Retrieve lists and list items
  • Create new items, including multi-level list items
  • Update existing list items
  • Delete outdated or incorrect items

All of this can be done programmatically, enabling real-time updates and seamless integration with external systems.

Key Benefits

Implementing this solution delivers tangible benefits:

  • Efficiency: Reduces manual effort and streamlines processes
  • Accuracy: Ensures consistent, up-to-date data across platforms
  • Scalability: Supports bulk operations and complex hierarchies
  • User Experience: Improves usability by presenting relevant, current options

Best Practices and Resources

The documentation also includes a detailed walkthrough, API sequences, performance guidelines, and error handling tips.
Use Case -List Management

For developers, a ready-to-use Postman collection is available on GitHub, making implementation faster and easier.
GitHub - SAP-samples/concur-web-services-list

Conclusion

Real-time list management with SAP Concur APIs offers a scalable, efficient way to keep your data accurate and aligned across systems. It reduces manual effort, simplifies integration, and improves the experience for both users and administrators.

entry.title: Re: Planned Depreciation for Following Month Showing Doub...
entry.content:
Hello @hyik 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Depreciation Using Half-Year and Annual Rates, Fixed asset, Fixed Assets Migrate Transactional Data (Write Down)

To summarise, the behaviour you described typically occurs when the migration posting does not correctly split between current year and prior accumulated depreciation values in S4H Asset Accounting subledger.

That could be caused by various reasons e.g., incorrect use of posting key in migration worksheet, you have a date mismatch between FI posting, you carried out migration as Acquisition instead of Transfer, and asset value date cut-off or missing transaction type differentiation. When you import assets mid-year through manual postings, the system does not automatically recognise that previous depreciation has been accounted externally. At the next depreciation run, the system posts the current period depreciation plus the missed Prior period adjustment and thereby effectively doubling for the first month.

When assets are migrated using manual postings and not via the legacy transfer transaction types, the depreciation engine assumes full-year calculation and adjusts the next period depreciation accordingly. Please refer to Fixed Assets Migration - Asset Value Date and Depreciation calculation Issue & Mid year assets Migration in S4HANA.

 I recommend you adhere to the public cloud Clean Core steps which includes:

Checking Depreciation Simulation to confirm double posting logic, verifying your FI migration entries, adjusting or re-migrating through Asset Transfer within Fiscal Year migration object and documenting your fix in migration workbook for auditing purpose.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Development of client-facing app in SAP BTP - Authent...
entry.content:
Hi Erick,

I personally would choose Option 2 for your use case and let IAS handle the identities. The identities and the authentication/authorization flow is fully in your hands, making operation easy. Also, you have power over additional security features like conditional access in case it's needed later down the road.

About Option 1) I believe it could be possible to let your app talk with XSUAA of the subaccount and manage authentication/authorization that way and maybe there's even a good reason to do so - more on that down below.

About Option 3) Building trusts from Cloud Identity Services to multiple third-party IdPs seems like a headache down the road regarding maintenance/operation. Also, you don't have in hand what they do with their IdP and can't troubleshoot the entire authentication flow properly.

One thing to consider in all of this - due to the low number of users you probably create them in the SAP Backend as well and do Principal Propagation via Cloud Connector. So far so good. But what if the solution needs to scale and you need more backend users and thus have more license costs?  Then an idea could be to indeed handle the authentication / authorization custom in your app and utilize a small number of technical users to talk to the backend accordingly.

Regards,
anotherbasicguy

entry.title: SAP MDG: Locking Supplier General Data When Data Already exists
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways to implement; this blog is written about one of them.

Create one custom class & redefine the standard class (CL_MDG_BS_ECC_HANDLER)

Method Responsible: IF_MDG_BS_BP_ACCESS_HANDLER~GET_ENTITY_PROPERTIES.

DATA: lv_crequest_type TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
      lv_cr_number     TYPE usmd_crequest,
      lo_app_context   TYPE REF TO if_usmd_app_context.

DATA: lo_data      TYPE REF TO data,
      lt_data      TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
      lt_msg       TYPE usmd_t_message,
      ls_msg       TYPE usmd_s_message,
      lt_erp_v     TYPE REF TO data.

FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lt_erpv> TYPE SORTED TABLE,
      <ls_erpv> TYPE any,
      <lv_erpv> TYPE any.

CALL METHOD cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context
  RECEIVING
    eo_context = lo_app_context.

IF lo_app_context IS BOUND.

  CALL METHOD lo_app_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crequest_type
      ev_process       = lv_process.

  lv_crequest_type = iv_crequest_type.

  CALL METHOD super->if_mdg_bs_bp_access_handler~get_entity_properties
    EXPORTING
      iv_entity         = iv_entity
      is_key            = is_key
      io_model          = io_model
      iv_crequest_type  = iv_crequest_type
      iv_crequest_step  = iv_crequest_step
      iv_crequest_index = iv_crequest_index
    CHANGING
      cf_read_only      = cf_read_only.

  IF iv_crequest_type EQ 'ZMDGS03'.
    io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      = 'BP_HEADER'
        if_active        = abap_false
        i_crequest       = lv_cr_number
      IMPORTING
        et_message       = lt_msg
        et_data_entity   = lt_data
    ).

    lt_erp_v = VALUE #(
      lt_data[ usmd_entity      = 'BP_HEADER'
               usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_VENGEN'
               struct           = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data OPTIONAL ).

    IF lt_erp_v IS NOT INITIAL.
      IF iv_entity EQ 'BP_VENGEN'.
        cf_read_only = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDIF.

SAP S/4HANA   SAP Master Data Governance   ABAP Development  

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Re: Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting
entry.content:
Hi David,

thank you for your feedback!

Formatting is done directly in the booklet via the side pane button "Formatting". Please see the in-app help, what is currently available there.

To put the sum line at the bottom (CM I to CM III with the elements above), you can currently switch off the hierarchy of the measure. In the booklet right-click on the Measure header, then select "Measure->Properties", then tab "Hierarchies", then un-check "Display hierarchically".

Then you will see the measures top-down. Unfortunately the summ line cannot be formatted as solid and underlined yet. For 2602 we plan to ship a new format template called "Report" which you can select under "Formatting->Templates" in the side panel of the booklet. Then you will see a formatted top-down list:

A cross-port of the booklet is planned for Private Cloud/OP, but I cannot confrim in which release.

Best regards,

Roman

entry.title: Latest Features in the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit, released with 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
Introducing the Latest Features in the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA

We're pleased to introduce the newest features in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, released with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 FPS0. These updates have been developed in direct response to customer feedback, aiming to elevate user experience and streamline migration processes.

New Staging and Direct Transfer Approach Features

Sequence Information View

A new feature is the Sequence Information View. This feature is designed to guide you in transferring data to your target system. It organizes migration objects in your project into a sequence for processing. This sequence is tailored to your specific project, depending on the migration objects you're working with.

By default, you'll see the Sequence Information View as your Start View, but you can easily switch back to the Standard View that you're used to.

Easier Access to Message Information

This improvement makes it simpler to navigate and access message-related information.

You can now easily trigger actions related to: 

  • Preparation Messages (only available for direct transfer): Get Information into the messages generated during Prepare Mapping Tasks.
  • Simulation Messages: Quickly access relevant information to better understand the outcomes of your simulation tasks.
  • Migration Messages: Get direct insights into the messages generated during the migration process, helping to troubleshoot and optimize your activities.
  • Migration Results: Access detailed information on the results of migration tasks, ensuring you have all the necessary data for review your migration tasks.

 These actions provide direct links to relevant message information, streamlining your navigation and increasing efficiency.

Server Group Assignment

This update offers you the ability to designate a specific application server or server group for your migration project, helping to ensure smooth operations without disrupting business activities.

To set this up, navigate go Job Management – Job Settings under the Option for Project. Here, you can select the application server or server group (if available) that best fits your needs.

Job Management

You now can adjust the number of background jobs assigned to specific migration objects, this offering a flexibility to streamline your data migration process according to your project's requirements.

To utilize this feature, go to Job Management under Jobs Used for Migration Objects, there you can see how many jobs are assigned to each migration object in your project.

Migration objects are categorized as following:

  • No Constraints: You can adjust the number of jobs assigned to the migration object.
  • Selection Process Only (1 Job for Simulation / Migration): Some objects, such as CO – Cost Center or CO – Profit Center, are limited to one job, so job adjustments aren't possible for them.
  • Staging Tables Not Prepared: Before adjusting job numbers, complete the Preparation step for these objects. (available for staging approach)
  • Status "Not Ready for Processing": If an object has this status, adjustments to job assignments are not possible

 For Staging approach, you can find more details in SAP KBA 294684 - SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit: List of Migration objects that doesn't support parallel jobs 

New Staging Features

Optimize Migration Performance

Migrating large volumes of data can be more efficient if you break it down into smaller packages. Once you've completed the "Prepare" step, you'll receive a recommendation on the number of jobs that can simultaneously handle a specific migration task. In the Job Management section, you have the flexibility to modify the number of background jobs dedicated to migration objects.

Efficient Error Handling When Uploading Template Files

The staging approach has been enhanced to display all sanity, duplicate, and consistency errors at once. This improvement means you no longer need to re-upload your file after each individual correction.

Any errors that arise during file upload are now provided in the template file, collected in the new “Messages” tab. In addition, a cell reference is available for each message which leads you directly to the error. After error correction, you need to delete the “Messages” tab and can upload the template file again.

See also following blog: SAP S/4HANA Migration cockpit: Easier Error Handling 

Correction File After Simulation

After a simulation ends with errors, you now have the option to use the "Create Correction File" action. This feature generates a file containing the specific instances of data that encountered errors during simulation.

This makes it straightforward to edit the issue-prone data within the file and re-upload it to the staging tables, like the Correction file feature available after Migration.

Download Template File (LTMOM)

You now have the capability to download Migration Object Template Files as CSV files, not only in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit but also in SAP S/4HANA migration object Modeler (LTMOM).

 

New Direct Transfer (DT) Approach Features

Object Versions

The system will update the status of a migration object when a new version is available. While new versions of migration objects will contain new features or bug fixes, migration objects can also be deprecated or retired. The system will also update the status of such migration objects to inform you that they will be unavailable in future releases.

Define Split Logic (LTMOM)

To generate multiple entries in the target parameter for each entry in a source table, you can define a split. There are two types of split logic available to tailor this process to your needs:

  • Simple Split Logic
  • Advanced Split Logic

 For more detailed information please see:

  • SAP Note: 3595079 Defining Split Logic - SAP S/4HANA Migration Object Modeler , especially the detailed guide attached
  • Blog from Philipp Kreutzheide: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit – Migrate Directly from SAP – Increase flexibility using Split Logic

Event Based Rules (LTMOM)

Event-based rules offer the capability to execute ABAP code at specific point of processing. To set up an event-based rule, you need to map a source table to a target parameter. Moreover, the target parameter must be a table, or a structure of type Importing, Changing, or Tables.

Class Based Source Code Rules (LTMOM)

Class-based source code rules offer an advanced option for defining how source values are transformed to target values. By creating an ABAP class with your own logic, you can create a class-based source code rule that utilizes this class. Additionally, these rules allow you to directly call other rules within the source code.

Utilizing Where Conditions Editor (LTMOM)

The WHERE Conditions Editor enables you to define additional selection criteria across all fields in a table using Open SQL statements. You can use AND and OR operations to build simple or complex conditions. You can leverage all ABAP Dictionary data types, with the exception of STRING, RAWSTRING, LCHR, and LRAW.

More details you can find in SAP KBA 3249988 - Details on selection process - SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit - Direct Transfer

Instance Field List (LTMOM)

You can define how migration object instance is displayed in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit. They are available under Instance List Settings button on the detailed screen for your root table.)

New Migration Objects

For details on the new migration objects, please check:

  • SAP S/4HANA – Release Comparison of Migration Object Templates (Staging Table)
  • SAP S/4HANA - Release Comparison of Migration Objects (Direct Transfer)

entry.title: Re: Payment ter determination
entry.content:
Hi Abbie,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the system pulls payment terms based on a hierarchy defined by the customer/partner function and the document type. The system will prioritize checking the Payment Terms field on the Business Partner record tied to the payer partner function for that specific sales area.

However, the terms are not typically retrieved into the G2 doc type from BP, they are determined in the CMR in the sales document, to then copied forward.  So to ensure the BP terms are always used, you must verify that the desired payment terms are defined on the payer's master record and that no other manual documents are overriding the value in the CMR document header.

entry.title: Hands-On Tutorial: Building an Autonomous Agent for Competitive Intelligence
entry.content:
In a fast moving market, knowing what your competitors are up to including product launches pricing changes and new content is essential for strategic decision making.
But manually tracking competitor websites and news is time consuming. In this tutorial we will build a hands-on solution leveraging the full power of the SAP BTP.
We will build an LLM-powered system that automatically crawls competitor websites for updates and answers your questions about those findings using a conversational agent.
The system combines an intelligent web crawler with an AI Agent to deliver the most relevant updates.
 
Note: Always ensure web crawling complies with each site's Terms of Service and robots.txt. Avoid crawling content that is private or protected. Use responsible rates and respect legal restrictions when collecting data.

Image 1: Agent for Competitive Intelligence

 A demonstration of the systems capabilities can be found here.

Solution Overview

The solution has two main components that work together.
1. Automated Web Crawler + Summarizer: A Python crwaler which periodically visits a competitors site, extracting both structured data including links and page hierarchy and unstructured data including the most relevant page content. Here we will use a Large Language Model to make intelligent decisions which links to follow and to classify pages as static (unlikely to change, e.g. press releases) and dynamic (frequently updated). All page data is stored in a SAP HANA Cloud database for persistence with content embeddings for semantic search generated automatically. After crawling the system produces a "Competitor Intelligence Briefing", a concise summary  of the latest relevant competitor activity.
2. AI Analyst Agent: An interactive AI Agent that can answer questions using two primary knowledge sources: (a) The internal database of crawled pages (b) the live internet. The agent uses tools and reasoning capabilities following the ReAct paradigm to answer questions. More in depth information on such an agent can be found in this blog on an conversational Agent with human-in-the-loop control I wrote or in this blog on a Q&A Agent Andreas Forster wrote.
 
Overall, the crawler keeps our internal knowledge base fresh and the AI Agents lets us query this internal data plus the latest public information.

 

Image 2: Conceptual Overview

Prerequisites and Setup

Before we take a closer look at the code, make sure you have the following ready:
  • Python 3.12
  • Access to SAP HANA Cloud (with database credentials to store data)
  • Access to the SAP AI Core
  • A target website URL

Installation: Clone the project repository and install the dependencies:

 
pip install -r requirements.txt
 
This will pull the necessary libraries, e.g. streamlit, langgraph, playwright, hana-ml.
Configuration: Create an .env file in the project root with your HANA DB connection details.
DB_ADDRESS=<your_HANA_hostname>
DB_USER=<your_db_user>
DB_PASSWORD=<your_db_password>
 
Make sure the SAP Generative AI Hub SDK is configured correctly such that init_llm() can connect to the LLM (visit this blog for more information).
With this setup now done let's run through all the components in more detail.

Part 1: Intelligent Web Crawler for Competitor Websites

The crawling system is implemented in start_crawling.py and helper modules. Its job is to explore the competitor site and record the content of each important page in the database.
Key features include:
Selective Site Exploration: Starting from the seed URL the crawler uses Breadth-First-Search to follow the page hierarchy. However, it doesn't blindly grab every link but uses LLM-based filtering to pick only relevant follow-up URLs that likely lead to meaningful content, e.g. articles or product page while avoiding irrelevant links.
Static vs. Dynamic Page Detection: Each page is analyzed to determine if it is a static or a dynamic page. Static pages are flagged such that the crawler can skip crawling them frequently.
Change Detection and Versioning: The crawler computes a hash of each page's content. If a page has been seen before, it compares the hash to detect updates. Changed pages get their content updated in the database with the old content saved as previous_content to keep a history of changes.
Database Storage (SAP HANA Cloud): All data lands in a HANA Cloud database table. A database table PAGES for the crawl data and a table SUMMARIES for the daily summary briefing.
Daily Summary Generation: After crawling the system automatically composes an executive summary of updates. This summary is saved to the DB and will be provided to the AI agent as initial context.

Crawling Strategy and LLM-Assisted URL Filtering

The crawler begins at the TARGET_URL and uses a queue to perform bread-first traversal of the site, respecting max depth. Here is the code of the crawl loop:
 
Spoiler
# In start_crawling.py
queue = deque([(base_url, None, 0)])
visited = {base_url}
while queue:
    current_url, parent_url, depth = queue.popleft()
    static = retrieve_page(conn, current_url, ['static'])
    #skip already known static pages
    if static: 
        continue 
    
    html_content = extract_site_content(current_url, return_raw_html=True)
    #Parse HTML and compute content hash
    if page_exists:
        if new_content_hash != old_content_hash:
            content = get_content(html_content)
            update_page(conn, page_id, new_content_hash, content)
    else:
        content = get_content(html_content)
        static = identify_static_site(current_url, html_content)
        add_new_page(conn, current_url, parent_url, static, new_content_hash, content)
    #Record processed pages
    if depth < MAX_DEPTH:
        follow_up_urls = get_urls(html_content, current_url, filter_prompt)
        for url in follow_up_urls:
            clean_url = url_normalize(url['url'])
            if clean_url not in visited:
                visited.add(clean_url)
                queue.append((clean_url, current_url, depth+1))
In this loop the crawler fetches a page, stores it in the DB, then discovers new links to follow. Note the call get_urls() which extracts candidate links from the page, then passes them through an LLM filter to identify legitimate follow-up links. The filter_prompt instruct the LLM with criteria for selecting these. By using this AI-based filtering the crawler focuses only on relevant content pages.
This intelligent filtering is very useful on complex sites as it tries to mimic what a human analyst would do while clicking through a site. You can adjust the filter_prompt to fit the specific structure of your target site.
Image 3 Flow Chart of Crawler Strategy

Identifying Static Pages to  Avoid Recrawling

Some pages  are essentially archives. Continuously recrawling them would be wasteful. Therefore we use identify_static_site(url, content) to classify pages. The prompt for this tool looks at URL patterns and page content cues to classify a page. For example a page containing /news/2025-08-29 or a page  with a visible "Published on August 29, 2025" is probably a static news article. When adding a new page to the database we store a Boolean flag static to avoid unnecessary recrawling.

Storing Pages and Detecting Changes in SAP HANA

All crawled data is saved in a HANA Cloud database with the following structure:
Image 4: Database Tables
Whenever the crawler fetches a page, it computes the new hash and compares with the stored one. If
different, the page is updated and the old content moved to previous_content.
Semantic Embeddings for RAG: Notice we also added an EMBEDDING colum to the PAGES table. This is a special vector column automatically generated by HANA using a pretrained language model. Essentially, as we insert the page content, HANA computes  a vector for the text via the function VECTOR_EMBEDDING( DOCUMENT, 'CONTENT', 'SAP_NEB.20240715'). Where  'SAP_NEB.
20240715' is the specific embedding model used. With this functionality in place: we can later perform semantic similarity search directly in SQL to power the agent answers.
Finally we create a SUMMARIES table. Each completed crawl will generate a new summary record.

Summarizing Updates with LLM

After the crawling loop finishes the script calls create_summary(). This function gathers all pages that were newly discovered or updated today from the database.
A powerful prompt is used here that instruct the model to generate a concise intelligent report. It explicitly states to synthesize new insight, grouping related changes into themes and highlight new vs updated content, as well as inferring a potential strategic intent behind the changes. The model then outputs a summary in a structured Markdown format.
This summary gets stored in the database. It is essentially an automated daily brief for your team. Even on
its own, this feature is valuable. Employees could read the brief each morning to stay informed. But our next step is to use this summary as an entry point for an interactive Q&A Agent.

Part 2: Building the AI Analyst Agent

With the crawler populating our internal knowledge base, the next component is an interactive AI Analyst Agent that end users can query for insights.

Tools for Knowledge Retrieval and Reasoning

To enable this hybrid knowledge search, we give the agent three main tools:
  1. Internal Data Retrieval rag() : Queries the SAP HANA Cloud database of crawled pages for relevant information. This tool finds pages from the competitor’s site that semantically match the user’s query. For instance, a question about “pricing changes” might retrieve the latest pricing page or a blog post from the competitor’s website that we collected. Is uses vector similarity search. Essentially it finds the top 5 pages with the content embedding closest to the query embedding. Under the hood we run a SQL Query with the COSINE_SIMILARITY on the EMBEDDING column.
  2. Live Web Search search_web() : Performs a real-time web search using a DuckDuckGo API to fetch recent public information. This is crucial for anything not on the competitor’s site, e.g. news articles or industry reports about the competitor. We typically limit results to a handful of relevant URLs to keep things focused.
  3. Page Content Extraction extract_site_content() : Given a URL, this tool fetches that webpage and extracts the text content. The agent uses this to read external pages on the fly. For example, after getting a URL from search_web(), it can call extract_site_content() to grab the details of that page, and even follow on-page links if needed.

Defining the Agent with LangGraph

LangGraph provides a prebuilt ReAct agent framework.

In agent.py we initialize the agent with our custom tools and a detailed system prompt. Here is how we create the agent:

# In agent.py
from gen_ai_hub.proxy.langchain import init_llm
from langgraph.prebuilt.chat_agent_executor import create_react_agent
...
tools = [extract_site_content, rag, search_web]
llm = init_llm('gemini-2.0-flash', max_tokens=1024, temperature=0)
agent = create_react_agent(llm, tools=tools, prompt=(system_message + briefing))

We use init_llm() to load the large language model over the SAP Generative AI Hub. Then create_react_agent() from LangGraph sets up the conversational agent that will use the provided LLM and tools. In this blog you can find a more detailed explanation on how to build an AI agent using LangGraph.

 
Behind the scenes LangGraph orchestrates these tools and the agent's reasoning process. The agent follows the ReAct loop. The language model analyzes the questions, then decides what tools to use, executes them to gather info and incorporates that info into the next steps. The model iterates until it has enough evidence to answer.
We won’t dive into the implementation code here. For readers interested in how the ReAct reasoning and LangGraph architecture work, see the previously published Human-in-the-Loop AI Agent blog post, which covers the agent loop and design in depth.

Why Combining Structured Crawling with Live Search Is Powerful

By now, the value of our hybrid approach should be evident. The internal crawler ensures that even if the
competitor quietly updates their website you have that info. The AI agent can
surface those insights on demand. Meanwhile, the web search ensures you don’t miss external perspectives.
Another benefit is that the agent can answer questions that go beyond the explicit content of one page by
synthesizing multiple pieces.

Conclusion and Next Steps

In this tutorial, we built a practical AI agent for competitor analysis that automates website monitoring and
provides an interactive Q&A interface for deeper analysis.
By using a crawler to build an internal database and an AI agent to generate insights, organizations can respond faster to competitor moves with well-informed decisions.
With the architecture in place, we have a flexible foundation. You can customize the LLM prompts to better fit your domain, adjust the crawling depth or frequency. Alltogether this powerful automation means your team spends less time gathering information and more time acting on it, turning competitor analysis into a proactive capability for your team.
 
Ready to outperform the competition with AI built on SAP BTP at your side?

entry.title: Logging Source IPs in SAP application logs when accessing SAP Applications thru SAP Routers
entry.content:
Hello,

We have deployed SAProuter to access some of our SAP applications.
Main advantage is that access to SAP application servers is restricted, but drawback is that the source IP from user workstation accessing SAP thru SAP GUI via our SAProuter is not available in SAP Security Audit Logs at application level.

Is there a way to configure SAP Routers to "forward" the source IP to SAP applications ?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Logging Source IPs in SAP application logs when acces...
entry.content:
It is not possible for SAPRouter to forward the source IP to the backend, as SAProuter only handles incoming connections and forwards the connections to the next target at the network level.

In scenarios where SAPGui and RFC connections are connected via the SAProuter, the source hostname (terminal name) is actually sent to the backend by the SAPGui/RFC client as part of the SAPGui/RFC protocol, and the backend can use this hostname/terminal name for security audit purpose.
However, the source hostname (or terminal name) may not be resolvable to an IP in the backend, depending on the network setup

Kind regards,
Product Support

entry.title: Re: How to handle errors for semantic key with number ran...
entry.content:
First of all: find the German Version here: Late Numbering für Non-Key-Fields

What WOULD be the best solution?

Here the AI is right: a LATE DETERMINATION (i.e., a determination AFTER validation) would be the way to success – unfortunately, this does not exist (although something similar might come one day).

What IS the best solution?

Well, tastes are known to differ, so depending on the use case, there is no single perfect solution, but in my opinion, there are 3 approaches (each with pros and cons):

1. UNMANAGED SAVE
2. ADDITIONAL SAVE (without EML)
3. ADDITIONAL SAVE (with EML)

What does this mean respectively? Let’s start with the explanation at bronze level and work our way up the ladder.

ADDITIONAL SAVE (with EML)

Here we would implement an ADDITIONAL SAVE, which runs in the late SAVE SEQUENCE – that is, after validation. However, at this point the entries are not yet persisted. So you would have to wait until this has happened... here the BgPF framework or a V2 poster could be used (although I don’t know whether it can even call EML?!?!?).
In this method, the new number is then drawn, and the object is changed or a change is triggered via an action in which the number is drawn. All this with EML.

Advantage

- It looks very professional because you are using a broad bouquet of new techniques...

Disadvantages

- Depending on the object, it may have a final, no-longer-changeable status based on the programming logic.
- Via EML we would go through the entire validation phase again, which can impact performance.
- This can also lead to effects in all directions, like determinations being executed AGAIN or similar.

ADDITIONAL SAVE (without EML)

We do the same as above, but instead of an EML call, the table entry is modified directly.

Advantage

It looks "dumber," but is significantly more robust due to less ping-pong through the RAP phases.

Disadvantage

Here we leave the RAP phases such as locking and similar. For example, before the number is reset, a new draft could be created (if the user clicks quickly or the application directly creates a new draft), which does not yet know the new number and simply deletes it from the database during save.

UNMANAGED SAVE

Here we come to the "best" approach – the UNMANAGED SAVE. Even in a managed scenario, you can be equipped with an UNMANAGED SAVE, which basically invites you to call "legacy APIs." But you can also write the changes into the database yourself based on the passed parameters such as CREATE, UPDATE, and DELETE – to avoid going through all hell during mapping, MAPPING FROM ENTITY helps here. But before writing, you quickly pull the desired number from the number range and put it into the field before writing.

If anyone asks why not change the values in ADDITIONAL SAVE via EML: In the late save phase, changing EML is **NOT** allowed because it would, in a way, jump out of the poster while it is running, as it would open a new interaction phase again.

Advantage

Exactly as intended by SAP: If the framework doesn’t do what you want, you can manually intervene here and be creatively flexible.

Disadvantage

You do updates directly on the database? I thought we were past that era, but apparently, you still need this druid knowledge in some places. Okay – besides my inner monk, there is another potential problem: If the object is extended with new entities, you must also consider these in the save method. This might not be a big deal in development but could drive some developer in the distant future to the brink of madness. Now bets can be placed: How often will this "UNMANAGED SAVE" be replaced by a regular save via the framework, only to find weeks or months later in production that "oh, something is broken now." In such cases, leaving comments in the code is highly recommended – the next generation will thank you! 😄

Conclusion

As the AI already knows by now, there is still no LATE DETERMINATION, so you have to find other ways, and I hope I was able to provide one or two thought-provoking approaches.

entry.title: Re: Displaying Serial numbers in custom cds views Report
entry.content:
Good day @Jaavani_1016 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Serial Numbers, CDS View Material, Custom CDS Views, The all new Custom CDS Views app

In summary, serial numbers are exposed in public cloud, only through released interface views e.g., I_SerialNumber. You cannot join directly to backend tables (OBJK, SER01, EQUI) due to clean-core restrictions.

The approach to take when trying to display serial numbers in a Custom CDS View or Analytical Query is:

  • First option is to build a Custom CDS View in Fiori (key user extensibility) joining I_MaterialDocumentItem à I_MaterialDocumentItemSerialNumber.
  • Another option is to use Developer Extensibility to define a CDS with a left outer join between these same released I_ views.
  • If you only need analytics, another option is to use Custom Analytical Queries on top of your published Custom CDS View.

Below is a step-by-side step guide to achieve the goal

Search Custom CDS Views --> click Create --> Data Source Type = Released View

Choose relevant data and click create.

You will be taken to the Custom CDS View editor. In the Primary Data Source section: Click Select Data Source, a pop up will open -->  filter by Released Views Only.

Next, add an association.

Click Add Association --> select View --> choose I_MaterialDocumentItemSerialNumber. Join Using MaterialDocument and MaterialDocumentItem. Set Join = Left Outer Join. Then select your required fields. Save and click check --> then publish

After publishing, your new CDS view will be available for reporting in Custom Analytical Queries or expose as an OData service through Custom Communication Scenario.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Logging Source IPs in SAP application logs when accessing SAP Applications thru SAP Routers
entry.content: That’s a great question — this is a common challenge when routing SAP GUI traffic through SAProuter. Unfortunately, SAProuter doesn’t natively forward the client’s original IP address to the application layer since it acts as a proxy and replaces it with its own. One workaround some teams use is enabling detailed SAProuter logs and correlating timestamps with the SAP Security Audit Log — not perfect, but useful for tracking sessions. Alternatively, setting up an intermediate reverse proxy or firewall that logs the true source IP before traffic hits SAProuter can help improve traceability. It would be great if SAP eventually added an option to preserve or forward the original client IP in future versions.
